author: William Fiuza

text:
I went to an American school overseas, and there was a kid a couple grades up that had this on a floppy drive in MIDI format; he’d let me borrow it and he then moved, and I was left with it. He’d always say that it was from a game by Squaresoft (we were both Square fans), but I could never remember the name, and the file was titled merely “Star Stealer”.

Fast forward to 2001, and I’m playing Chrono Cross; “Star-Stealing Girl” comes on, and my heart drops. I still get chills when I hear this song, and it’s one of my favorites to this day.

author: Jonathan Goldberg

text: Sorry guys, I've been so out of touch with my fabled Japanese gaming history for a couple of years now (Been so busy trying to establish my life, pushing through work and paying bills). However, the music and the thematics of Japan's (Square's, Capcom's, Konami's, Atlus', etc.) greatest games have and will never leave my mind and my heart.
author: Jonathan Goldberg

text:
*Sighs* I can sense familiars nuances of musical pieces derived from Chrono Trigger, Chrono Cross and Xenogears. Well, the songs from Radical Dreamers and the other games mentioned do come from the same composer after all: Yasunori Mitsuda.

I know the name of the song from Chrono Cross but I never heard of the Square game of the same name. What's it about and how does it relate to the Chrono games?

author: Cheeseman

text: @SupraDarky I'll give that this wasn't as good as the other two, but it does have plenty of good points you have to wonder why they dropped in Cross. The characterization was much better for the majority of the characters, Magus was in RD(he was planned for Cross, but dropped toward the end of development), and the connections to Trigger were much stronger. Even if not very successful, it'd be nice if we could get some form of Radical Dreamers anywhere outside of Japan.

text: It's interesting to see the development of this song, as it reappears in Chrono Cross. A lot of the songs and story for Chrono Cross were seen in beta version in Radical Dreamers. This makes it a really interesting game, but only if you're a hardcore Chrono fanboy (there's a translation patch). Otherwise, it's pretty forgettable.
